0.text:
Human history doesn’t always move in a straight
line. Sometimes we take one step forward,

5.text:
then stumble a few back, only to turn around
and leap daringly into an unknowable future.

10.text:
This is a 2,600 year timeline of these most
pivotal moments, the revolutions that created

19.text:
Ancient Rome was a violent, vengeful place.
Lucius Tarquinius Superbus, the seventh King,

25.text:
took power after orchestrating the assassination
of his predecessor. Tarquinius then moved

30.text:
quickly to execute senators who were disloyal
to him, freeing him to embark on a string

35.text:
of successful conquests. But the Roman public
eventually grew angry at their king’s relentless

40.text:
demands. And when Tarquinius’ son Sextus
raped a noblewoman who then killed herself

45.text:
out of shame, the public’s outrage boiled
over. Lucius Junius Brutus, head of the king’s

51.text:
personal bodyguard, seized the moment, and
convinced the legislators to exile Tarquinius.

56.text:
The Roman Republic was thus established with
Brutus elected co-consul. His first act was

61.text:
swearing a collective oath with his people
to never again allow a man to become king

68.text:
82 years later, commoners and slaves rose
up in Corcyra during the fifth year of the

73.text:
Peloponnesian war. After seizing power, they
successfully resisted the more powerful Athenians

78.text:
and other forces who attempted to take the
city by sea.

82.text:
The Maccabean Revolt saw lighter, quicker
forces achieve a series of decisive victories

87.text:
over the slower, bulkier army of the Seleucid
Empire--an event that returned the practice

91.text:
of Judaism Jewish worship to Jerusalem and
is commemorated today with the observation

96.text:
A century of frequent warfare and civil unrest
in Rome culminated with Augustus becoming

101.text:
emperor. This dramatic end to the Roman Republic
shifted power away from the people and began

107.text: the first phase of the Roman Empire.

110.text:
Zooming forward nearly 800 years, we see one
of history’s most-well organized revolutions:

116.text:
the Abbasid family’s overthrow of the Umayyad
Caliphate. This moment marked the end of the

120.text:
Arab empire and the beginning of a more multiethnic
Middle East.

125.text:
The central Italian city-state of Florence
lurched through a period of great change at

129.text:
the end of the Middle Ages. In 1252 it introduced
the florin. Europe’s first gold coin of

135.text:
significance in over five centuries, it’s
popularity made Florentine bankers extremely

140.text:
rich. But these newly powerful mercantile
elites didn’t like to share power, forcing

146.text:
the oppressed labor class to rise up and seize
control of the government. Observing this,

152.text:
the banker Cosimo de’ Medici chose to use
his immense fortune to rule from behind the

157.text:
scenes for three decades. This move toward
obscurity paid off, as three members of his

162.text:
family became Pope. In 1530, a Spanish siege
and capture ended the Republic, but not before

169.text:
it’s infamously cut throat political system
was immortalized in Machiavelli’s “The

173.text:
Prince,” a influential treatise by the founder
of modern political science.

178.text:
Later in the 16th century William of Orange
led a revolt against the Spanish crown. This

183.text:
started the Eighty Years’ War, which eventually
resulted in the founding of the independent

187.text:
Dutch Republic, the first successful secession
in European history.

192.text:
The nine year English Civil War resulted in
a King losing his head, the Church of England

197.text:
losing much of its influence, the monarch
losing power to Parliament, and 11% of the

201.text:
total population of England, Scotland, and
Wales losing their lives through either plague,

208.text:
With the English crown severely weakened,
the unpopular King James II - a Catholic - was

213.text:
unable to stop his Protestant son-in-law William,
the leader of the Netherlands, from invading.

219.text:
After King James fled to France, parliament
accepted his daughter and son-in-law as co-regents,

224.text:
only after they signed the 1689 Bill of Rights.succeeded
him as Queen and began the famous reign of

229.text:
A century after the fall of King James II,
the thirteen American colonies on the other

232.text:
side of the Atlantic determined their “rights
as Englishmen” were being infringed by the

237.text:
tyrannical King George and declared themselves
free and independent states in July 1776.

244.text:
Forced out of Boston, British “redcoats”
held New York City for the entire war, but

248.text:
the English were ultimately defeated by the
Americans who were led by the brilliant General

253.text:
George Washington, who had formed a pivotal
alliance with the French. The revolutionaries

258.text:
founded the United States of America and adopted
a democratic constitution--triggering a wave

264.text: of political change around the world.

266.text:
That wave crashed onto the shores of France
in 1789, when an overtaxed people embarked

272.text:
on a violent 10-year revolution to overthrow
the monarchy and establish a republic. Inspired

278.text:
by the Americans, and the ideas of the European
enlightenment, the Bastille was stormed, the

283.text:
rights of man and citizen were declared, feudalism
was abolished, democracy was established,

289.text:
freedom of religion was embraced, and civil
rights were won for blacks, gays, and jews.

294.text:
Although the revolution included the Reign
of Terror, and set the stage for the dictatorial

298.text:
conquests of Napoleon, the dynamic France
that emerged became a vital beacon of liberty.

304.text:
The French Revolution sought to benefit humanity
as a whole, and is one of the most pivotal

309.text:
moments in modern history, accelerating the
rise of republics and democracies throughout

315.text:
Two years after the French Revolution began,
blacks in the French colony of Saint Domingue

320.text:
on the island of Hispaniola launched history’s
greatest slave uprising. In cooperation with

326.text:
their former biracial rivals, a massive black
insurgency threw aside the plantation system,

331.text:
and under the command of Jean-Jacques Dessalines,
successfully ended the Revolution by defeating

336.text:
the French army in the Battle of Vertieres.
This defining moment in racial history challenged

342.text:
long-held beliefs of black inferiority. The
rebels’ organization and tenacity shocked

347.text:
and frightened slaveholders. And the Haitian
Revolution is the only slave uprising in history

353.text:
to lead to the founding of a free state ruled
by non-whites and former captives.

358.text:
Taking their cue from the Americans, French,
and Haitians, Latin America rose up against

363.text:
their Portuguese and Spanish colonial rulers
so suddenly that every country on the mainland

368.text:
but two gained their independence in the fifteen
years between 1810 and 1825.

375.text:
Back in Europe, 1830 saw a slew of revolutions
around the continent. Belgium seceded from

380.text:
the Kingdom of the Netherlands, the Swiss
peacefully took to the streets to force constitutional

385.text:
reform, France overthrew King Charles X, Italy
unsuccessfully attempted to unite, Portugal

392.text:
endured a civil war, and there was a failed
revolution in Poland against the Czar of Russia.

398.text:
Eighteen years later, the most widespread
revolutionary wave in history hit Europe and

402.text:
parts of Latin America as democratic movements
took aim at dismantling feudal structures

408.text:
once and for all. Again, France provided the
spark when it brought down the Orleans monarchy.

414.text:
Before long, over 50 countries were experiencing
unrest, but amazingly, there was no coordination

420.text:
between the various revolutions. There didn’t
need to be. Squalor, famine, and disease were

425.text:
rampant and a groundswell of dissatisfaction
had spread throughout the poor and working

429.text:
classes of Europe. Loosely formed revolutionary
coalitions broke down and tens of thousands

435.text:
were killed. Even more fled, with many crossing
the Atlantic to the United States. When the

441.text:
dust settled, what initially seemed like a
series of failed movements turned out to be

446.text:
a period of significant upheaval. Serfdom
was abolished in Austria and Hungary, Denmark’s

452.text:
absolute monarchy ended, and parliamentary
democracy was introduced in the Netherlands.

457.text:
By the middle of the 19th century a feudal
military dictatorship in Japan had been in

462.text:
power for seven centuries. But in 1868, the
last shogun - Tokugawa Yoshinobu - was ousted

468.text:
in a coup and a new young emperor named Meiji
became the supreme executive authority. Yoshinobu

473.text:
lost a brief civil war and as a result, Meiji
moved the government to the former shogun

476.text:
capital of Edo and renamed it Tokyo, meaning
“eastern capital.” What followed was a

481.text:
period of rapid modernization that included
the construction of Japan’s first railroad,

486.text:
telegraph lines linking all major cities,
and the creation of a European-style banking

491.text:
system. With the introduction of the Meiji
Constitution that established a democratically-elected

496.text:
parliament, the stage was set for an industrialized
Japan to rise over the next century.

502.text:
After overthrowing the 30-year dictatorship
of Porfirio Diaz, Mexico experienced a ten-year

507.text:
struggle between multiple armed rebel groups
who fought both amongst themselves and with

512.text:
the government. Eventually, the fighting subsided
and a constitutional republic was established.

518.text:
In China, it took many revolts and uprisings
to overthrow 2,000 years of imperial dynasty,

525.text:
but with the abdication of Puyi, the six-year-old
“Last Emperor” in 1912, the dawn of the

531.text: Republic of China was at hand.

533.text:
For more than 300 years, the Romanov dynasty
ruled Russia, but by 1917, the people had

539.text:
had enough of Tsar Nicholas II. The government
was corrupt and horribly inefficient. The

545.text:
event that finally broke the people’s will
was World War I, which killed more than 2.5

550.text:
million Russians, who had trouble matching
the Germans on the battlefield. When food

551.text:
riots in the capital, Petrograd, turned into
an open revolt, the Tsar was forced to abdicate.

558.text:
Wisely, his brother also said “no thanks”
to the throne, ending the dynasty for good.

563.text:
The provisional government that followed actually
wanted to continue the war, but within months

567.text:
it too had collapsed in the face of an organized,
relentless communist opposition. The Bolsheviks,

574.text:
led by Vladimir Lenin, seized power, moved
the capital to Moscow, ended the war, fought

579.text:
off challenges by counter-revolutionaries
and rival socialists, and established the

584.text:
Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the USSR,
in 1922.

590.text:
Meanwhile, the German people suffered many
of the same hardships as the Russians. In

594.text:
the winter of 1918, food and fuel shortages
hit just as the deadliest flu epidemic in

600.text:
human history was sweeping the world. The
imperial government of Wilhelm II fell, replaced

606.text:
by the Weimar Republic, a semi-presidential
representative democracy.

611.text:
Another consequence of World War I was the
collapse of the Ottoman empire. Mustafa Kemal,

615.text:
a successful military officer, lead the resistance
to Soviet, Greek, Italian, and French occupation

621.text:
all at once. After Tukey’s territorial boundaries
were in place, Kemal became the country’s

626.text:
first president, the caliphate was abolished,
and in 1928 Turkey officially became a purely

633.text:
The defeat of Germany in World War I caused
great suffering and resentment among its people,

639.text:
creating the perfect conditions for the successful
propaganda campaign of Adolf Hitler. His furiously

646.text:
nationalist, far-right Nazi party took power
in 1933 when Hitler was appointed Chancellor

652.text:
of Germany. The Nazi’s used intimidation
and violence to consolidate authority, then

658.text:
embarked on the military conquests that set
off World War II.

662.text:
In the pacific theatre of the second world
war, Indonesia declared its independence in

667.text:
1945 the same day its Japanese rulers surrendered
to the Allies. After initially struggling

673.text:
with Dutch efforts to manage it as a colony,
Indonesia emerged as a free state in 1949

680.text:
with revolutionary hero Sukarno becoming its
first President.

684.text:
The independence movement in India lasted
an astounding 190 years. First, revolutionaries

690.text:
had to free themselves from the powerful East
India Company, then take on the British Empire.

695.text:
After making massive contributions to the
British victories in both World Wars, the

700.text:
Indian people were growing increasingly frustrated
at their second-class status. By 1920 a lawyer

706.text:
named Mahatma Gandhi had emerged as one of
the most influential leaders in the history

711.text:
of the world. He energized and inspired the
Indian people with his nonviolent non-cooperation

717.text:
movement, which included a spectacular 3 ½
week protest march to the sea, and multiple

722.text:
imprisonments for acts of civil disobedience.
Decades passed, but after the Labour Party

728.text:
was victorious in the 1945 British parliamentary
elections, a new stance toward India was adopted,

735.text:
allowing for India to negotiate its independence
in the summer of 1947. This was a bitter-sweet

740.text:
moment for Gandhi, for self-government came
at a high price: instead of remaining unified,

745.text:
British India was partitioned into two nations,
India and Pakistan.

750.text:
The 1949 Revolution was the culmination of
the 28-year rise of the Chinese Communist

756.text:
Party. During World War II the communists
formed an alliance with their rivals, the

761.text:
Chinese Nationalist Party, in order to defeat
Japan. When the Japanese surrendered to end

766.text:
the war, the Communists and Nationalists rushed
to take over territory and assets, and before

771.text:
long, they were fighting one another. Since
the Nationalists controlled the government,

775.text:
they had superior numbers and commanded the
air force, but the Communists - led by their

780.text:
Chairman Mao Zedong - were better organized.
Before long, the Communists began piling up

786.text:
military victories, bringing more and more
cities under their control. By August 1948

792.text:
inflation had reached extreme levels, and
soon the cities of Suzhou, Tianjin, Beijing,

798.text:
and the then-capital, Nanjing, all fell into
communist hands. Defeated, the Nationalists

803.text:
took the air force, navy, and most of the
government’s gold reserves, and reestablished

808.text:
itself on the island of Taiwan. In control
of the mainland, Mao declared Beijing the

813.text:
capital of the newly established People’s
Republic of China, which he ruled for 27 years

818.text: as an autocrat until his death in 1976.

822.text:
There were two Vietnams in 1946: a communist
north and a noncommunist south. After fighting

828.text:
an eight year war of independence with the
French, the cease-fire terms awarded freedom

832.text:
for the North, the communist Democratic Republic
of Vietnam territory only as far south as

838.text:
Egypt’s monarchy was overthrown in 1952
in favor of a Republic led by the charismatic

842.text:
army officer Gamal Abdel Nasser. The revolution
was committed to the establishment of a single

847.text:
Arab state, which achieved some success by
briefly merging with Syria into one country,

853.text:
but that joint state and that idea ultimately
failed.

857.text:
Fidel Castro and his brother Raul led an armed
revolt against the dictatorship of President

863.text:
Fulgencio Batista, who they eventually ousted
in 1959. The Castros replaced Batista’s

869.text:
pro-American government with a communist regime
that’s still in power today.

874.text:
After the movement for Algerian independence
began during the first world war, France promised

879.text:
to eventually grant the north African nation
its independence. The Algerians were patient,

884.text:
and tried to win their freedom through peaceful
means. However, when they protested they were

888.text:
met with violence and endured massacres that
killed as many as 40,000 people. In October

894.text:
1954, an uprising spread quickly throughout
the country. The French reaction was forceful

899.text:
and extreme. It poured more than two million
troops into the eight year war, including

904.text:
a one-time installation of 500,000 soldiers
in the capital. But the effective use of guerrilla

909.text:
warfare, outbreaks of terrorism, and sustained
rebel control of mountainous areas wore the

914.text:
French down. Charles de Gaulle, the President
of France, eventually allowed Algerians to

920.text:
vote on their independence. The referendum
passed with over 99.7 percent support. The

926.text:
Algerian Revolution was an important decolonization
war and led to the loss of French prestige

933.text:
The Derg is the short name for the military
council that took power in Ethiopia after

937.text:
the fall of Emperor Haile Selassie. To impose
its will, the communist Derg executed and

942.text:
imprisoned tens of thousands of opponents
without trial.

946.text:
Two key events hastened the fall of the fascist
dictatorship of premier Marcelo Caetano. One

952.text:
was the the regime’s attempts to force army
officers to fight unpopular colonial wars.

957.text:
The other was the publication of a book called
“Portugal and the Future” by war hero

961.text:
General Antonio de Spinola, who convincingly
argued against Caetano’s leadership. Around

967.text:
250 military officers orchestrated a bloodless
coup, sending Caetano into exile. Some Portuguese

974.text:
demonstrated by placing carnations in soldiers’
guns. Rival political groups tried to fill

979.text:
the power vacuum, propelling the country through
a series of dramatic shifts in leadership.

984.text:
But the people were determined to shape their
future, and in 1975 an election for the national

989.text:
assembly drew 92 percent of eligible voters
to the polls--a record in the history of western

995.text:
Europe. The colonial occupations ended and,
by the end of the 20th century, with the military

1001.text:
withdrawn from politics, Portugal’s system
of democracy had become solidified.

1006.text:
What was initially an uprising against forced
cotton cultivation in Angola turned into a

1011.text:
struggle to liberate the entire colony from
Portuguese control. After the revolution in

1015.text:
Portugal brought a new government to power,
it withdrew all of its forces from the country

1020.text:
in 1975. After a brief civil struggle, Angola
officially gained its independence.

1026.text:
Mozambique also freed itself from Portuguese
colonial rule. With the support of the Soviet

1031.text:
Union and China, it fought a decade long guerrilla
war to win a negotiated independence in 1975.

1039.text:
The communists (called the Khmer Rouge) won
the Cambodian civil war and installed a government

1044.text:
led by Pol Pot. Pot’s totalitarian dictatorship
committed one of the worst genocides in history,

1051.text:
killing 25 percent of Cambodia’s eight million
people in just four years.

1057.text:
In 1953 the American and British helped remove
Iran’s Prime Minister in a coup so the westerners’

1063.text:
prefered leader, the Shah, would continue
his rule unchallenged. Shah is another term

1068.text:
for “king.” By the late 1970’s the Shah’s
reign was going on four decades. Despite a

1073.text:
swiftly expanding economy, many Iranians felt
left behind by the pace of modernization.

1079.text:
As protests against the Shah intensified,
a religious leader named Ayatollah Ruhollah

1084.text:
Khomeini who’d been living in exile for
fifteen years, quickly gained a groundswell

1089.text:
of populist support. When the government resorted
to violence against the uprising, it became

1094.text:
clear the regime had lost its credibility,
and the Shah fled the country. Khomeini returned

1099.text:
to Tehran and was greeted by more than one
million supporters in the capital. In a rejection

1104.text:
of western values, Iran became an Islamic
Republic and Khomeini its first Supreme Leader.

1110.text:
The Somoza family’s dynasty in Nicaragua
lasted for 43 years until the Sandinista National

1116.text:
Liberation Front mounted a sustained, years
long insurgency that brought it down in July

1121.text:
1979. But the real battle was just beginning
as the Sandinista government, backed by the

1127.text:
Soviet Union, fought an eight year civil war
with the Contras, a militant group funded

1132.text:
by the United States. Fortunately, a 1987
peace agreement shifted the focus from combat

1139.text:
The 21-year authoritarian rule of Philippine
President Ferdinand Marcos ended when Corazon

1145.text:
Aquino, the widow of an assassinated opposition
leader, challenged her nation to hit the streets

1150.text:
in massive displays of public disobedience.
Marcos tried to rig the election, but the

1155.text:
people revolted and Aquino became president,
the first woman in Asia to hold that title.

1161.text:
A major split between the Soviet Union and
China in 1960 broke the unity of the communist

1167.text:
bloc. From that moment on, the sun was setting
on the USSR. For a time, it stood tall against

1173.text:
the U.S.-led western alliance in many conflicts
and struggles for power during the Cold War,

1178.text:
but when communism began collapsing in eastern
Europe, Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev

1184.text:
stood by as the dominos fell. Poland was the
first country to switch to a democratic government,

1189.text:
and Lithuania was the first to declare its
independence from the USSR. These events set

1194.text:
off a wave of change, and by the end of 1991,
14 countries had declared independence from

1199.text:
the Soviet Union. What was left became Russia,
which also had a democratically elected, anticommunist

1205.text:
leader. The Cold War had come to an end. And
with the world’s dominant supporter of communism

1209.text:
gone, the rest of the world quickly abandoned
the ideology too.

1214.text:
The racially discriminatory and segregationist
system of apartheid in South Africa, where

1219.text:
a smaller white population dominated the economic
and political rights of a larger black majority,

1225.text:
came to a close after years of negotiation
allowed a truly democratic election in 1994.

1232.text:
The winner was the revolutionary hero Nelson
Mandela.

1235.text:
Yugoslavian President Slobodan Milošević
was overthrown after repressing his opponents,

1241.text:
refusing to let go of power, and ordering
his forces to commit war crimes during the

1245.text:
Kosovo conflict. NATO action helped bring
a swift end to the bloodshed and Milošević

1251.text:
Twenty days of protests against the ineffective
government of Georgia culminated in opposition

1256.text:
leader Mikheil Saakashvili storming a Parliament
session while carrying a red rose. Two months

1262.text:
later he won the presidency in an unopposed
election. He then embraced a pro-Western foreign

1268.text:
policy and declared European integration as
his main priority, creating tensions with

1273.text: Russia that continue to this day.

1276.text:
A leaked audio recording of Ukraine’s President
ordering the kidnapping of a journalist helped

1281.text:
fuel protests against his government’s poor
handling of the economy. Around 20% of the

1286.text:
country participated in the Orange Revolution
that made opposition leader Viktor Yushchenko

1292.text:
president, after surviving poisoning in a
failed assassination attempt.

1297.text:
The presidency of Kurmanbek Bakiyev in Kyrgyzstan
collapsed after his government became increasingly

1302.text:
authoritarian and corrupt. When he tried to
rig his reelection the people revolted and

1309.text:
In December 2010 a street vendor in Tunisia
lit himself on fire to protest the humiliation

1315.text:
and harassment he suffered at the hands of
a corrupt government. Inspired by his incredible

1320.text:
act of self sacrifice, thousands of Tunisians
filled the streets to protest high unemployment,

1326.text:
inflation of food prices, corruption, and
a lack of political freedom. Just 28 days

1331.text:
later President Ben Ali fled the country.
Soon, the entire Arab world was hit with a

1337.text:
wave of demonstrations, protests, riots, coups,
and civil wars. For the first time, the world

1342.text:
was seeing the power of sms social media and
the Internet as a revolutionary tool. Many

1347.text:
of the civil uprisings were met with violent
responses from authorities. Hundreds of thousands

1352.text:
have died and millions have fled from the
large scale conflicts that erupted: the Syrian

1357.text:
Civil War, the Iraqi civil war with ISIS,
the Egyptian Crisis and ousting of President

1362.text:
Hosni Mubarak, the Libyan Civil War that killed
Muammar Gaddafi, and the crisis in Yemen.

1368.text:
Although the ultimate outcome of the Arab
Spring is not yet known, so far only the Tunisian

1373.text:
revolution has resulted in constitutional
democratic governance.

1378.text:
In November 2013 Ukrainian President Viktor
Yanukovych refused to sign a deal he had previously

1384.text:
agreed to that would’ve created a closer
relationship between Ukraine and the European

1389.text:
Union. Instead, he agreed to terms with Russia
after President Vladimir Putin offered $15

1394.text:
billion in loans in exchange for rejecting
the EU deal. This last minute reversal triggered

1400.text:
demonstrations that intensified for several
months. After hundreds of thousands took to

1406.text:
the streets of Kiev, filling the Maidan square,
violent clashes broke out with police, killing

1411.text:
more than 100 people. In day five of the violence,
Yanukovych fled to Russia and was replaced

1417.text:
by a pro-Western interim government. Putin
responded by sending Russian troops, disguised

1422.text:
as Ukrainian separatists, to occupy and ultimately
annex the Ukrainian controlled territory of

1428.text:
Crimea. Its blatant violation of the territorial
sovereignty of another nation resulted in

1433.text:
sanctions against Russia and the condemnation
of the international community.

1437.text:
Well I hope you enjoyed this jam-packed rundown
of the world’s most important revolutions.

1442.text:
Thanks for watching. Make sure to follow us
on Twitter and Facebook where we curate the

1447.text:
day’s most interesting news stories. Links
below.

1450.text: Until next time, I’m Bryce Plank.
